thread.title: Emerging-market currencies just had their best week of the year
thread.title_full: Emerging-market currencies just had their best week of the year - MarketWatch

author: Joseph Adinolfi
title: Emerging-market currencies just had their best week of the year
text:
Emerging-market currencies are having a spectacular week.
Currencies across the developing world have recorded huge gains against the dollar since last Friday, when the weaker-than-expected September jobs report kicked off a rally in the space.
The dollar has risen substantially against most of its emerging-market rivals this year as investors prepared for an imminent interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve, which would make the dollar more attractive by increasing the return on deposits and dollar-denominated assets.
But a Fed hike this year is looking increasingly uncertain. This has benefited the dollar’s rivals.
The Indonesian rupiah was the leader with a 9.2% gain against the dollar, followed by the Russian ruble, with a 7.3% gain. The Malaysian ringgit and the Brazilian real—two of this year’s worst-performing currencies—posted respectable weekly gains of 6.4% and 4.8%.
These gains represent the best weekly performance for the ringgit, real and rupiah against the dollar this year. Strong gains across the sector have made this past week one of the best for emerging-market currencies: “If not the best, then definitely one of the best,” said Piotr Matys, an emerging-markets currency strategist at Rabobank.
Emerging-markets currencies have been battered over the past year by the expectation that the Federal Reserve will soon raise interest rates. Since Jan. 1, the ringgit has fallen nearly 18% against the dollar, while the real is down 40%—and that is after this week’s gains.
The week’s gains are also notable because several emerging-markets currencies, including the ringgit, the Turkish lira and the real, were trading at record lows only weeks ago.
These declines left the currencies overstretched to the downside, and primed for a rally, Matys said.
Stabilizing crude oil prices, and strength among global equities, has also helped stoke investor appetite for risk, sending money back into the developing world, said Ilan Solot, vice president of emerging-market currency strategy at Brown Brothers Harriman.
Crude oil futures traded on Nymex posted a more than 9% rebound this week.
That is especially important for emerging-market economies like Russia and Malaysia, that are large crude oil exporters.
But emerging-market bulls should hold off on declaring this the beginning of the EM bull market.
With the Fed still on track to raise interest rates in December, or soon thereafter, the prospect of higher rates in the U.S. will likely continue to siphon capital out of the developing world in favor of a higher return in America.
“EM currencies aren’t out of the woods just yet against the dollar,” Matys said.
Here’s a chart of how the rupiah has traded against the dollar this year.
